The boy who 
 nobody loved 
 
 Phumy Zikode 
 English 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Once upon a time, there was a boy who
 was so ugly that nobody loved him, even
 
 his parents. 
 
 At home, he would sit alone while his
 
 family watched television. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 At schol, you would find him siting 
 alone while other children were playing. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 2  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 When they went to fetch the catle, you
 
 would find him walking behind al the
 other boys because they didn’t want to
 walk with him. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 3  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 One day he decided to leave, but he didn’t
 know where he would go. He walked until
 he got to an indigenous forest. 
 
 
 He started to get scared but was
 comforted by the thought that nobody
 
 would speak to him because nobody
 loved him. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 4  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 When he was about to enter the forest, 
 an old, dirty, ugly woman came up to him. 
 
 She greted him and asked what he was 
 doing in the scary forest. 
 
 
 The boy was shocked to hear someone 
 speaking to him. He told the old woman 
 
 that he wasn't going anywhere because 
 no one loved him. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 5  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The old woman asked if he neded help.
 He responded quickly and said “Yes”.
 The old woman said that before she
 
 helped him, she wanted him to lick her
 face until she was clean and beautiful.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 6  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The boy didn’t have any other option but 
 
 to lick the old woman’s face in order to 
 get the help he neded. He started 
 licking the slep from her eyes, the snot 
 
 from her nose and the wax from her ears. 
 He licked her face until she was clean 
 
 and beautiful. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 7  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The old woman thanked him. She said,
 “You wil find many wonderful things in
 the forest, but don’t take any of these
 
 things. Only bring back the rot that you
 find.” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 8  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The boy ran, wanting to se al of those
 things in the forest. But before he could
 
 enter the forest, the old woman caled
 him. She said, “Boy! Come back here!”
 
 
 He ran back to her and said, “I’m here”.
 She asked him if he had heard what she
 
 said to him. “I said you wil find many
 wonderful things in the forest, but don’t
 
 take any of these things. Only bring back
 the rot that you find,” she repeated. The
 boy noded and so the old woman 
 
 alowed him to go into the forest.
 
 
 
 
 
 9  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The boy ran of, but before he could enter 
 the forest, he heard a voice saying, “Boy! 
 
 Come back here!” He started to be 
 confused about what the old woman 
 wanted. He ran back to her. 
 
 
 She said, “I don’t think you heard me 
 properly. I said you wil find many 
 
 wonderful things in the forest, but don’t 
 take any of these things. Only bring back 
 
 the rot that you find.” The boy noded 
 and ran back to the forest. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 10  
 
 
 
 
 
 Just after he had entered the forest, he 
 
 heard a voice again saying, “Boy! Come 
 back here!” He tried to ignore the voice 
 
 but it continued so he went back to the 
 old woman. 
 
 
 The old woman said, “I don’t trust you. I 
 don’t think you’l do what I ask you to do. 
 You wil find many wonderful things in 
 
 the forest, but don’t take anything. Only 
 bring back the rot that you find.” The 
 
 boy was becoming anoyed with the 
 repetition. He ran until he was in the 
 forest. 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Once he was in the forest, he saw a bowl
 filed with money. He tok the money and
 
 put it in his pocket. Al of a suden, he
 thought about what the old woman said,
 that he mustn’t take anything except the
 
 rot. 
 
 
 He tok the money out his pocket and
 put it back in the bowl. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 12  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 He loked around and saw some 
 
 splendid new clothes. He tok of the 
 clothes he was wearing and put on the 
 new ones. Again he thought about what 
 
 the old woman had said. He tok of the 
 new clothes and put his old ones back 
 
 on. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 13  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 He loked around and saw the rot. It 
 was withered from the sun. He asked 
 himself what the old woman thought he 
 
 would do with the rot. Next to the rot, 
 there was a bowl of fod. The fod 
 smeled delicious and the boy was 
 
 hungry. He couldn’t stop himself from 
 eating. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 14  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 When he had finished, he remembered
 
 what the old woman had told him. He
 remembered that the old woman had
 said he must only take the rot.
 
 
 He loked around for the rot, but he
 
 couldn’t se it. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 15  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 He went back, feling disapointed, to
 tel the old woman what had hapened.
 
 But the old woman was gone. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 16
